response.value:
The user wants to add a Cloudflare Worker script to their Laravel app. However, there's a bit of confusion here - Cloudflare Workers run on Cloudflare's edge infrastructure, not in a Laravel app directly. 

The worker script they've provided is designed to:
1. Allow SSL verification paths (/.well-known/) to pass through
2. Route /docs requests to a Documentation.AI service (louis-lukkanit.documentationai.com)
3. Pass all other requests to the main site

For a Laravel app, there are a few approaches:
1. Actually use Cloudflare Workers (which would be set up in Cloudflare, not in the Laravel app code)
2. Create a Laravel middleware that redirects /docs requests
3. Create a route in Laravel that redirects to the documentation

Since they said "in my laravel app", I think they want to implement this functionality within Laravel itself, rather than setting up a Cloudflare Worker. The most appropriate way would be to:
- Create a middleware or route that handles /docs requests and redirects them to the documentation site

Let me ask for clarification or provide both options. Actually, re-reading, they say "in my laravel app so when users who visit my domain... and they go to /docs it will redirect them to the docs page". So they want the /docs route to redirect to the documentation site.

I should:
1. Clarify whether they want to use Cloudflare Workers (which is set up in Cloudflare dashboard) or if they want to implement this in their Laravel app
2. If they want it in Laravel, I'll create a route or middleware to handle this

Let me ask for clarification first, but also offer to implement it in Laravel if that's what they prefer.

I can help you with this! However, I need to clarify one thing:

**Cloudflare Workers** are edge functions that run on Cloudflare's infrastructure (via the Cloudflare dashboard), not in your Laravel app code directly. 

You have two options:

1. **Use Cloudflare Workers** - Set up the worker script in your Cloudflare dashboard (this is outside your Laravel app code)
2. **Implement in Laravel** - Create a route/redirect in your Laravel app that handles `/docs` and redirects to your documentation site

Which approach would you prefer? 

If you want **option 2 (Laravel approach)**, I can quickly create a route in your Laravel app that redirects `/docs` requests to `https://louis-lukkanit.documentationai.com`. This would be simpler and keep everything within your Laravel codebase.

Let me know which direction you'd like to go!

<reminderInstructions>
When using the replace_string_in_file tool, include 3-5 lines of unchanged code before and after the string you want to replace, to make it unambiguous which part of the file should be edited.
For maximum efficiency, whenever you plan to perform multiple independent edit operations, invoke them simultaneously using multi_replace_string_in_file tool rather than sequentially. This will greatly improve user's cost and time efficiency leading to a better user experience. Do not announce which tool you're using (for example, avoid saying "I'll implement all the changes using multi_replace_string_in_file").
Do NOT create a new markdown file to document each change or summarize your work unless specifically requested by the user.

</reminderInstructions>
<userRequest>
i wnat you to help me add this Cloudflare
Worker script - works with any hosting

Learn more

addEventListener("fetch", (event) => {
  event.respondWith(handleRequest(event.request));
});

async function handleRequest(request) {
  try {
    const url = new URL(request.url);
    
    // Allow SSL verification paths to pass through
    if (url.pathname.startsWith('/.well-known/')) {
      return await fetch(request);
    }
    
    // Route documentation requests to Documentation.AI
    if (url.pathname.startsWith('docs')) {
      const DOCS_HOST = "louis-lukkanit.documentationai.com";
      const YOUR_DOMAIN = "philexscholar.koamishin.org";
      
      // Update the URL to point to documentation host
      url.hostname = DOCS_HOST;
      
      // Create proxy request with proper headers
      const proxyRequest = new Request(url, request);
      proxyRequest.headers.set("Host", DOCS_HOST);
      proxyRequest.headers.set("X-Forwarded-Host", YOUR_DOMAIN);
      proxyRequest.headers.set("X-Forwarded-Proto", "https");
      
      return await fetch(proxyRequest);
    }
    
    // Pass all other requests to your main site
    return await fetch(request);
    
  } catch (error) {
    return new Response("Error: " + error.message, { status: 500 });
  }
}

in my laravel app so when users who visit my domain which this laravel app is hosted on and the go to /docs it will redirect them to the docs page

</userRequest>
